Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.

I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. T

Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that

I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personal

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other

In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent pe

I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

B

Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.

I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people can be well

I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispa

I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives th

Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Tel

I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.

Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better educ

Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.

Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role.  How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.

In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell t

I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice

I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunites. That doesn't mean they are

Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunites. That doesn't mean they are all gang banger,

In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.

In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.

Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else.

I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.

Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes

That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.

Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed int

Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time. I

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.

In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time.

Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time.

Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time. 

Hollywood thrives on making money and if something is working fo

That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time. 

Hollywood thrives on making money and if something is working for them they will

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.

Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time. 

Hollywood thrives on making money and if something is working for them they will continue to prod

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time. 

Hollywood thrives on making money and if something is working for them they will continue to produce it. I guess

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time.

In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time. 

Hollywood thrives on making money and if something is working for them they will continue to produce it. I guess the movies with negative sterot

Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time. 

Hollywood thrives on making money and if something is working for them they will continue to produce it. I guess the movies with negative sterotypes of minori

Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time. 

Hollywood thrives on making money and if something is working for them they will continue to produce it. I guess the movies with negative sterotypes of minorities must be mon

In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time. 

Hollywood thrives on making money and if something is working for them they will continue to produce it. I guess the movies with negative sterotypes of minorities must be money makers. Wha

---

In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time.

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time. 

Hollywood thrives on making money and if something is working for them they will continue to produce it. I guess the movies with negative sterotypes of minorities must be money makers. What if they weren't any longer? W

Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time. 

Hollywood thrives on making money and if something is working for them they will continue to produce it. I guess the movies with negative sterotypes of minorities must be money makers. What if they weren't any longer? Would tha cau

That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time. 

Hollywood thrives on making money and if something is working for them they will continue to produce it. I guess the movies with negative sterotypes of minorities must be money makers. What if they weren't any longer? Would that cause the

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.

Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time. 

Hollywood thrives on making money and if something is working for them they will continue to produce it. I guess the movies with negative sterotypes of minorities must be money makers. What if they weren't any longer? Would that cause the writers to thin

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time. 

Hollywood thrives on making money and if something is working for them they will continue to produce it. I guess the movies with negative sterotypes of minorities must be money makers. What if they weren't any longer? Would that cause the writers to think outside the

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time. 

Hollywood thrives on making money and if something is working for them they will continue to produce it. I guess the movies with negative sterotypes of minorities must be money makers. What if they weren't any longer? Would that cause the writers to think outside the box and see the

I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time. 

Hollywood thrives on making money and if something is working for them they will continue to produce it. I guess the movies with negative sterotypes of minorities must be money makers. What if they weren't any longer? Would that cause the writers to think outside the box and see the world as it re

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time. 

Hollywood thrives on making money and if something is working for them they will continue to produce it. I guess the movies with negative sterotypes of minorities must be money makers. What if they weren't any longer? Would that cause the writers to think outside the box and see the world as it really is and not

Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time. 

Hollywood thrives on making money and if something is working for them they will continue to produce it. I guess the movies with negative sterotypes of minorities must be money makers. What if they weren't any longer? Would that cause the writers to think outside the box and see the world as it really is and not as it was in t

In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time. 

Hollywood thrives on making money and if something is working for them they will continue to produce it. I guess the movies with negative sterotypes of minorities must be money makers. What if they weren't any longer? Would that cause the writers to think outside the box and see the world as it really is and not as it

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the most offensive stereotypical characters are the ones that are portrayed as being stupid, lazy, or just plain evil. I see this a lot with the Black population, and I am getting tired of it. Maybe I am seeing things inaccurately, but it is annoying show after show and movie after movie to see Black people portrayed in the drug dealer role. Portrayed as living in areas of poverty and high crime, and being in a character that seems to lack education and intelligence. I don't know if this is true or not, but it is what I see. 
I have seen this with the Hispanic population as well.
 How many movies come out that are talking about cartels and how they are running the Hispanic neighborhoods? When these stereotypes are perpetuated in Hollywood, they are perceived as being real in everyday life. You can only see something so many times before you start to believe it must be true. Hollywood and studios need to take a real look at the movies they are producing. Maybe it's time to tell writers of these type of stories that enough is enough. I personally don't ever need to see another movie about inner city gangs killing each other or kidnapping innocent people. These things happen, but they happen with groups of white people, as well.  

Black and Hispanic people have normal everyday lives the same as the majority white population. Telling stories of the struggle for better education or getting the job they deserve may be something people would appreciate more. Let's begin to tell the situation as it is. That because of prevalent racism and prejudice in this country, minorities don't have the same opportunities. That doesn't mean they are all gang bangers, drug dealers, or low life thugs. They are citizens and humans trying to live like everyone else. It is offensive to different cultures and races, and quite frankly my intelligence, when stereotypes are allowed to be portrayed in the media time after time. 

Hollywood thrives on making money and if something is working for them they will continue to produce it. I guess the movies with negative sterotypes of minorities must be money makers. What if they weren't any longer? Would that cause the writers to think outside the box and see the world as it really is and not as it has been in th
